title: 106_hr2838
content: There is no information provided in the prev_chunk to assist with summarizing the curr_chunk. The Secretary of the Treasury will oppose any financial assistance to the Government of Indonesia from international financial institutions. Congress believes these institutions should withhold approved loans or assistance to Indonesia. The US government restricts financial assistance to Indonesia from international financial institutions and prohibits military-to-military cooperation and support for Indonesia. The US restricts financial assistance and military cooperation with Indonesia. Funds under certain provisions of law may not be available for military financing, assistance, or training in Indonesia. Licensing exports of defense articles or services to Indonesia is also restricted. The President should coordinate with other countries for multilateral efforts, especially in the Asia-Pacific region. The US restricts financial and military cooperation with Indonesia, including limiting funds for military financing and exports of defense articles. The President should work with other countries, especially in the Asia-Pacific region, to develop a comprehensive strategy in line with this Act. Exception: Section 1 does not apply to providing food or medical aid to Indonesia or East Timor for humanitarian reasons. Conditions for ending these measures are outlined in Section 3. The measures in Section 1 apply to the Government of Indonesia until certain conditions are met in East Timor, including a safe environment, freedom of movement, and implementation of the results of the 1999 vote on East Timor's political status. The Armed Forces of the Republic of Indonesia is conducting itself in a manner consistent with its responsibilities to its citizens and international commitments. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. Congress believes the US should support an international peacekeeping force for East Timor.
